awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Developing Technology for Stimulating the Herd Instinct of Livestock to Improve Environmental Impact
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to help restore grassland ecosystems and reduce net greenhouse gas emissions from livestock by developing technology to stimulate the herd instinct of livestock. Grassland ecosystems have been shown to benefit from large herds of animals that promote water absorption and replenish important nutrients. However, most livestock in the western United States are currently scattered in large pastures and allowed to roam individually.  This project aims to develop and test low-cost ear tags which use audio and electrical stimulation to reinforce the natural herd instinct of individual animals when they stray from the group. High stock density/low duration grazing has demonstrated the potential of reducing livestock greenhouse emissions and turning rangelands into a net carbon sink. Higher vegetation diversity, more water absorption, reduced erosion, and more wildlife habitat are just some of the expected ecological benefits of this technology. This technology could also facilitate more efficient and cost-effective ranch management. The risk of livestock theft will be reduced, and the need for fences would decrease since the migratory instincts of livestock work best on larger land areas. 

This SBIR Phase I project will develop and test a novel approach of stimulating the herd instinct of livestock rather than geographically confining them. Key to the implementation of this approach is the additional innovation of a unique and low-cost strategy to use ear tags with low-power radiofrequency (RF) transceivers to calculate herd proximity from an accumulation of individual distance estimates. This technology will use a highly integrated system using an ear tag attached to each animal in the herd. Each tag will use a low power RF transceiver to periodically send brief signals to the other tags in the herd. The tags will use signal strength measurements to calculate their own approximate distance to every other tag. Each tag will then use an algorithm to determine whether it is within an appropriate proximity to the rest of the herd. If an animal begins to stray from the herd, the tag will give an audio alert potentially followed by electrical stimulation to encourage the animal to rejoin its peers. The capability of holding a herd at a density from 10,000 to 1,000,000 pounds per acre will be a key metric of success.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Phase I project to develop and test Herd Instinct (HI) tags has demonstrated the feasibility of using simple ear tags to keep livestock together in a herd. Two prototype versions were developed and built in batches of twenty, and the second version was tested on cattle in live field trials for one month. The tags functioned even better than expected in keeping the livestock together as a herd. No increase in negative behavior was observed in the animals with the herd instinct tags. The herd instinct tags did not increase the stress level of the animals, and the cattle demonstrated an ability to learn and adapt to the technology over time so that the number of audio and electrical stimulation events decreased during the live trials.

The successful proof of concept of this technology represents a significant leap forward in the potential study of herd behavior, grassland ecosystems, and wildlife. In the past there have been considerable challenges with maintaining cattle together as a herd within specific ecosystems. In certain terrains, such as deserts or mountainous regions, conventional solutions like electric fencing were unfeasible, and virtual fencing technologies were inadequate due to their infrequent refresh rates. This made it challenging to maintain a high enough herd density for detailed studies on the impacts of the herd on soil and grass quality.

Herd instinct stimulation technology introduces a novel solution to these longstanding challenges. It also provides the capability to gather vast amounts of data on the movement and behavior of cattle and other livestock. Researchers can now construct grazing intensity maps over set time periods, indicating how much time livestock spend in specific pasture areas.

One key advantage of this innovative technology is its affordability, which facilitates scaling up research to examine the effects of larger herds. It also allows for precise adjustment of herd density, thereby providing researchers the opportunity to investigate the impact of specific animal weight per acre. This critical feature will aid in determining the optimal herd densities for varying environments and landscapes.

The current development of herd instinct stimulation technology ushers in an era of more effective, detailed, and scalable research in herd behavior, ecosystem dynamics, and livestock welfare. Overcoming the limitations of past methods has opened up exciting new possibilities for future studies in these critical areas.

Beyond enhancing the scope and efficacy of research on animal behavior and herd density, the technology developed during this NSF project has transformative potential for studying soil health and the environmental impact of animals. For the first time in over a century, scientists will be equipped to easily recreate conditions that mimic those when bison and other large native ungulates were the prevailing species on the landscape.

Definitive data on the impacts of rotational grazing has, in the past, been somewhat elusive, despite indications that with proper management practices, it can significantly enhance the health of grasslands and their capacity to absorb methane. Herd instinct stimulation technology should make it possible to correct this shortfall in data.

With the advent of Herd Instinct tags, researchers now have the means to conduct more comprehensive, longer-term studies on a larger scale. These in-depth investigations will shed light on the effects of grazing management practices patterned after historic migratory grazing. The resulting insights could help redefine our understanding of the interplay between animal behavior, herd management, soil health, and environmental preservation. Ultimately, this innovative technology enables a new era of enriched scientific knowledge, setting the stage for sustainable practices that are harmonious with the natural world.
